data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve a specific series by ID
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves detailed information for a specific series identified by its unique ID. Returns a Series resource object containing metadata such as title, description, and relationships to associated seasons, episodes, networks, and classifications. Requires authentication via API token. The response conforms to the JSON:API specification.

message: Operation 'get_/classification_inclusions' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Original summary is generic. Description explains filter requirements well but lacks clarity on return value and pagination. Enhanced summary to be action-oriented and added explicit return value information for better AI agent understanding of what to expect.

data.current_description:
Classification Inclusions connect classifications with entities like series, episodes, or campaigns, amongst others.

In order to retrieve a set of classification inclusions, at least one of the following filter parameters must
be provided. Failing to do so renders a `400 Bad Request` response.

- `ids[]`
- `classified_id` and `classified_type`
- `classified_id` and `classification_type`
- `classification_id` and `classified_type`
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve classification inclusions with required filters
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a collection of ClassificationInclusion records that connect classifications with classified entities (series, episodes, campaigns, etc.). data.current_description:
One initial filter must be provided (`ids`, `series_id`, or `season_id`), otherwise a `400 Bad Request` response
will be returned. Additional filters are allowed.

This API will only return episodes that your credential has permission to access, which may not be exclusive to
your account, depending on the filter(s) being used. Be careful to filter the results as needed.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve episodes with required initial filter
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a paginated collection of Episode resources. Requires at least one initial filter: `ids[]`, `series_id`, or `season_id`. Omitting an initial filter returns a `400 Bad Request` error. Additional filters are supported for refined results. Returns only episodes accessible to your credential, which may include content beyond your account depending on filter criteria. Returns a collection of Episode objects with associated metadata and relationships.

data.current_description:
Each series, season, and episode has a Credits section where you may add people and roles.
This is an internal tool to recognize contributors. It is not related to ART19 users or account permissions.
Each Person added will have no additional access or permissions granted as a result of being included in the Credits section.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve paginated list of credited people
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a paginated list of people who have been credited in series, seasons, or episodes. This endpoint provides access to the internal credits database for recognizing contributors. Note: Credits are for attribution purposes only and do not grant ART19 user access or account permissions. Supports filtering, sorting, and pagination parameters. Returns a JSON:API collection of person resources with their associated credit information.

message: Operation 'get_/images' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details, missing_output_details. Summary is too generic ('Get a list of images'). Description, while comprehensive about image styles, lacks clarity about pagination requirements, filtering capabilities, and what the operation actually returns. Improved summary to indicate pagination and filtering support. Condensed description to focus on operation mechanics while preserving essential style information.

data.current_description:
An image represents a piece of artwork attached to some entity like a series, season, or episode,
and is _owned_ by an entity called the `bucket`.
An image is also a container for several `MediaAssets` representing the physical files for various
styles used.

## Media Asset Styles for Images

Most media assets use square images. You may upload and use a square image, or upload an image of any
shape and crop it to a square by specifying the cropping area. This area â identified by a coordinate
`x, y` and a `width` & `height` â is the portion of the image used for all cover art. If an image has
cropping defined, the cropped version of the image will be used in any `regular` or `square` style of media
asset. If the original file is rectangular and does not have cropping, then the system will use a squared
version of the original file with the smaller of width or height as the square size.

The original image as uploaded into the system is always retained unmodified and available through
the style `original`. All media asset styles except `stripped-original` consist of the cropped image.

An image has media assets with the following styles:

- `original`: This is the original file provided. May not be available, depending on permissions
  and file type.
- `stripped-original`: The original file with all metadata (EXIF, XMP, PNG metadata, etc.) removed.
  This should be used for any application needing the original, uncropped, image.
- `regular`: If the image has cropping defined, this is the cropped image.
  If not, this is a square version of the original.
- `thumb`: A square thumbnail of the image with a size of `100x100` pixels.
- `square-400`: A square version of the image with a size of `400x400` pixels.
- `square-640`: A square version of the image with a size of `640x640` pixels.
- `square-888`: A square version of the image with a size of `888x888` pixels.
- `square-3000`: A square version of the image with a size of `3000x3000` pixels.
  This variant is only created if the cropped width & height are each at least 3000.
- `itunes`: A square version of the image with a size of `1400x1400` pixels.

### Preferred image used in feeds

For the main series image used in feeds, it is ideal to use the `square-3000` version.
If that is not available, the `itunes` version should be used instead.
data.summary_suggestion: List images with pagination and filtering
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a paginated collection of images. Images represent artwork attached to series, seasons, or episodes and contain multiple MediaAssets in different styles (original, thumb, square-400, square-640, square-888, square-3000, itunes, etc.). Supports filtering and sorting via query parameters. Pagination is required. Returns an array of image resources with their associated media assets. Requires authentication via API token.
data.reasoning: Summary is too generic ('Get a list of images'). Description, while comprehensive about image styles, lacks clarity about pagination requirements, filtering capabilities, and what the operation actually returns. Improved summary to indicate pagination and filtering support. Condensed description to focus on operation mechanics while preserving essential style information.

data.current_summary: Get a list of media assets
data.current_description:
A media asset is part of a collection of assets or files representing an image or a piece of audio content
like an episode or an ad. Images, for example, have differently sized versions for better rendering performance,
and a piece of audio content usually comes in different encoding formats.

The `style` attribute of a media asset describes the role an asset plays in the context of the collection.
The collection is what an asset is attached to (`attachment_id|type`).

## Styles for Images

Most media assets use square images. You may upload and use a square image, or upload an image of any
shape and crop it to a square by specifying the cropping area. This area â identified by a coordinate
`x, y` and a `width` & `height` â is the portion of the image used for all cover art. If an image has
cropping defined, the cropped version of the image will be used in any `regular` or `square` style of media
asset. If the original file is rectangular and does not have cropping, then the system will use a squared
version of the original file with the smaller of width or height as the square size.

The original image as uploaded into the system is always retained unmodified and available through
the style `original`. All media asset styles except `stripped-original` consist of the cropped image.

An image has media assets with the following styles:

- `original`: This is the original file provided. May not be available, depending on permissions
  and file type.
- `stripped-original`: The original file with all metadata (EXIF, XMP, PNG metadata, etc.) removed.
  This should be used for any application needing the original, uncropped, image.
- `regular`: If the image has cropping defined, this is the cropped image.
  If not, this is a square version of the original.
- `thumb`: A square thumbnail of the image with a size of `100x100` pixels.
- `square-400`: A square version of the image with a size of `400x400` pixels.
- `square-640`: A square version of the image with a size of `640x640` pixels.
- `square-888`: A square version of the image with a size of `888x888` pixels.
- `square-3000`: A square version of the image with a size of `3000x3000` pixels.
  This variant is only created if the cropped width & height are each at least 3000.
- `itunes`: A square version of the image with a size of `1400x1400` pixels.

### Preferred image used in feeds

For the main series image used in feeds, it is ideal to use the `square-3000` version.
If that is not available, the `itunes` version should be used instead.


## Styles for Audio

- `medium`: A medium-quality version of the audio asset in various formats.
- `original`: This is the original file provided. May not be available, depending on permissions
  and file type.
- `waveform_data`: The generated BBC Audiowaveform data in JSON or binary format.
data.summary_suggestion: List media assets with pagination and filtering
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a paginated collection of media assets representing image or audio files. Media assets are attached to content entities (series, seasons, episodes, ads) and available in multiple styles: for images (original, stripped-original, regular, thumb, square-400, square-640, square-888, square-3000, itunes) and for audio (medium, original, waveform_data). The `style` attribute indicates the asset's role. Supports filtering and sorting via query parameters. Pagination is required. Returns an array of media asset resources. Requires authentication via API token.
data.reasoning: Summary is too generic. Description is comprehensive but lacks clarity about pagination requirements and filtering capabilities. Improved summary to indicate pagination and filtering support. Condensed description to focus on operation mechanics while preserving essential information about available styles and use cases.
